item.title: Group: Global airline profits thin this year
item.description: Squeezed by high oil prices, the world airline industry's profit will be slim this year and could be wiped out if Europe tumbles into recession, the global aviation trade group said Monday.
item.media:text: Squeezed by high oil prices, the world airline industry's profit will be slim this year and could be wiped out if Europe tumbles into recession, the global aviation trade group said Monday.

item.title: Commerce Sec. Bryson cited for felony hit-and-run
item.description: U.S. Commerce Secretary John Bryson was cited for felony hit-and-run following two Los Angeles-area traffic crashes that left him injured and unconscious, police said Monday.
item.media:text: U.S. Commerce Secretary John Bryson was cited for felony hit-and-run following two Los Angeles-area traffic crashes that left him injured and unconscious, police said Monday.

item.title: US students survive 9 days in New Zealand bush
item.description: Two U.S. students trapped in the New Zealand wilderness by a snowstorm trekked back out to safety after surviving their nine-day ordeal by rationing their meager supplies of trail mix and warming themselves in hot springs.
item.media:text: Two U.S. students trapped in the New Zealand wilderness by a snowstorm trekked back out to safety after surviving their nine-day ordeal by rationing their meager supplies of trail mix and warming themselves in hot springs.

item.title: French Open Men's Final: Live Report
item.description: 1149 GMT: Djokovic 4-6 3-6 6-2 5-5 *Nadal - Nadal suddenly very defensive, waiting for Djokovic to force the pace - the Spaniard sends up a lob which the Serbian dispatches to go to 30-15. Its followed by a great rally that Djokovic ends with another winner. A big serve and Nadal's return is out - huge applause from the crowd who are sensing the importance of that hold. And now the sun is out!
item.media:text: 1149 GMT: Djokovic 4-6 3-6 6-2 5-5 *Nadal - Nadal suddenly very defensive, waiting for Djokovic to force the pace - the Spaniard sends up a lob which the Serbian dispatches to go to 30-15. Its followed by a great rally that Djokovic ends with another winner. A big serve and Nadal's return is out - huge applause from the crowd who are sensing the importance of that hold. And now the sun is out!

item.title: China loans rise could show government steps gain traction
item.description: BEIJING (Reuters) - China's bank lending in May rose more than expected, suggesting fast-tracked infrastructure projects were creating loan demand and that measures to counter a sharpening economic slowdown may be taking affect. New loans figures followed a flurry of May data at the weekend, which reinforced the view China is heading for its sixth quarter in a row of slowing growth and helping to explain a surprise interest rate cut last week - Beijing's boldest action yet to underpin economic activity. ...
item.media:text: BEIJING (Reuters) - China's bank lending in May rose more than expected, suggesting fast-tracked infrastructure projects were creating loan demand and that measures to counter a sharpening economic slowdown may be taking affect. New loans figures followed a flurry of May data at the weekend, which reinforced the view China is heading for its sixth quarter in a row of slowing growth and helping to explain a surprise interest rate cut last week - Beijing's boldest action yet to underpin economic activity. ...

item.title: Afghans: Ambulance hits roadside bomb; 5 dead
item.description: An ambulance struck a roadside bomb while rushing a pregnant woman and her family to a hospital in northern Afghanistan on Monday, killing the woman and four of her family members, the Interior Ministry said.

item.title: Two ex-US college football players shot dead at party
item.description: Two former US college football players were among three people shot dead at a pool party near Auburn University, a renowned powerhouse in the sport, Alabama police said Sunday.
item.media:text: Two former US college football players were among three people shot dead at a pool party near Auburn University, a renowned powerhouse in the sport, Alabama police said Sunday.

item.title: Rain halts Djokovic-Nadal final at French Open
item.description: For the first two sets, Rafael Nadal looked like the King of the Clay, alternately bullying Novak Djokovic, then frustrating him, as Djokovic tried to solve the nearly unsolvable riddle of Nadal at Roland Garros.
item.media:text: For the first two sets, Rafael Nadal looked like the King of the Clay, alternately bullying Novak Djokovic, then frustrating him, as Djokovic tried to solve the nearly unsolvable riddle of Nadal at Roland Garros.

item.title: HBO documentarians look for Bush the man
item.description: Tourism officials in Maine will be delighted when they see HBO's new documentary on President George H.W. Bush.

item.title: Police probe crashes linked to commerce sec.
item.description: Police are investigating two traffic collisions allegedly caused by U.S. Commerce Secretary John Bryson that left him injured, authorities said Monday.
item.media:text: Police are investigating two traffic collisions allegedly caused by U.S. Commerce Secretary John Bryson that left him injured, authorities said Monday.

item.title: U.S. Commerce secretary investigated for hit-and-run car crash
item.description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Secretary of Commerce John Bryson is being investigated for several hit-and-run car crashes in Southern California on Saturday that police say appear to have been caused by the Obama administration official. The San Gabriel Police Department, in a statement released early Monday, said a preliminary investigation indicates Bryson caused the first crash when his Lexus rear-ended a Buick in the city on Saturday at about 5:05 p.m. He hit it again when leaving the scene. ...
item.media:text: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Secretary of Commerce John Bryson is being investigated for several hit-and-run car crashes in Southern California on Saturday that police say appear to have been caused by the Obama administration official. The San Gabriel Police Department, in a statement released early Monday, said a preliminary investigation indicates Bryson caused the first crash when his Lexus rear-ended a Buick in the city on Saturday at about 5:05 p.m. He hit it again when leaving the scene. ...

item.title: Suspect sought in Auburn shooting that killed 3
item.description: Authorities searched Monday for a gunman suspected of killing three people and wounding three others in a weekend shooting at a pool party near Auburn University that a witness said began with a fight over a woman.
item.media:text: Authorities searched Monday for a gunman suspected of killing three people and wounding three others in a weekend shooting at a pool party near Auburn University that a witness said began with a fight over a woman.

item.title: Study: Even 7-year-olds sometimes hurt themselves
item.description: Even children as young as 7 sometimes cut themselves on purpose, according to a small study believed to be the first to examine self-injury at such early ages.

item.title: Lebanese rivals hold talks on Hezbollah's arms
item.description: Rival Lebanese factions have resumed a national dialogue on defense that could eventually integrate the militant Hezbollah group's arsenal into the Lebanese regular army.

item.title: NY Giants lineman Diehl charged with DWI
item.description: New York City police say Giants offensive lineman David Diehl (deel) has been charged with driving while intoxicated.

item.title: Axelrod says voters will judge Obama on actions
item.description: Senior political adviser David Axelrod says he doesn't think voters will make much of President Barack Obama's remark that the private sector is doing fine.

item.title: Rescue loans for Spain's banks buys Europe time
item.description: A $125 billion plan to rescue Spain's banks won't solve Europe's debt crisis or ease the pain of double-digit unemployment across the continent.
item.media:text: A $125 billion plan to rescue Spain's banks won't solve Europe's debt crisis or ease the pain of double-digit unemployment across the continent.

item.title: Fires force Syrian rebels to scout new trails to Turkey
item.description: YAYLADAGI, Turkey (Reuters) - Syrian rebels are having to find new and more difficult routes to smuggle refugees and wounded civilians and fighters into Turkey after Syrian government forces began torching wooded areas along the border this month. The deliberate fires appear to be a new tactic by forces loyal to Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to flush out hiding rebels and stop civilians escaping. Syrian troops began laying mines along the same border months earlier. ...

item.title: Analysis: EU's Spain bank rescue may bring only brief respite
item.description: PARIS (Reuters) - Euro zone finance ministers rushed Spain into an EU-funded rescue for its debt-stricken banks to pre-empt the threat of a bank run if Greece's debt crisis flares again but any respite for Madrid and the euro may be short-lived. After weeks of insisting that Spain needed no assistance to recapitalize lenders crippled by bad debts from a burst real estate bubble, Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy was pushed into requesting an aid package for fear of worse disaster to come, European officials involved in the negotiations said. ...

item.title: FACT CHECK: Looming tax hike not the biggest ever
item.description: Republicans are calling it "Taxmageddon," the big tax increase awaiting nearly every American family at the end of the year, when a long list of tax cuts are scheduled to expire unless Congress acts.
item.media:text: Republicans are calling it "Taxmageddon," the big tax increase awaiting nearly every American family at the end of the year, when a long list of tax cuts are scheduled to expire unless Congress acts.

item.title: Independent bookstores embrace digital publishing
item.description: Clare Dickens only wanted to share her story to help others. But in the process, she became a successful independent author — with the help of a local bookstore and its instant publishing machine.
item.media:text: Clare Dickens only wanted to share her story to help others. But in the process, she became a successful independent author — with the help of a local bookstore and its instant publishing machine.

item.title: Spain rescue sends world stocks surging
item.description: A European agreement to bail out Spain's banks sent stock markets surging Monday, but analysts warned that the deal doesn't solve all of the continent's problems, and the goodwill could be short-lived.
item.media:text: A European agreement to bail out Spain's banks sent stock markets surging Monday, but analysts warned that the deal doesn't solve all of the continent's problems, and the goodwill could be short-lived.

item.title: 10 Things to Know for Monday
item.description: Your daily look at late-breaking news, upcoming events and the stories that will be talked about today (times EDT):
item.media:text: Your daily look at late-breaking news, upcoming events and the stories that will be talked about today (times EDT):

item.title: Japanese man climbs all world's 14 tallest peaks
item.description: A Japanese mountaineer who was nearly killed by an avalanche in 2007 finished a climb in Nepal last month that made him his country's first person to scale the world's 14 tallest mountains.
item.media:text: A Japanese mountaineer who was nearly killed by an avalanche in 2007 finished a climb in Nepal last month that made him his country's first person to scale the world's 14 tallest mountains.

item.title: Gordon Brown challenges Murdoch for misleading inquiry
item.description: LONDON (Reuters) - Former Prime Minister Gordon Brown accused media tycoon Rupert Murdoch on Monday of misleading a government-sponsored inquiry into press ethics with incorrect testimony alleging Brown had threatened war against Murdoch's company. "This conversation never took place. I am shocked and surprised that it should be suggested," Brown told the Leveson inquiry. "This call did not happen. The threat was not made." "I find it shocking," Brown said."This did not happen. There is no evidence that it happened other than Mr Murdoch's but it didn't happen. ...
item.media:text: LONDON (Reuters) - Former Prime Minister Gordon Brown accused media tycoon Rupert Murdoch on Monday of misleading a government-sponsored inquiry into press ethics with incorrect testimony alleging Brown had threatened war against Murdoch's company. "This conversation never took place. I am shocked and surprised that it should be suggested," Brown told the Leveson inquiry. "This call did not happen. The threat was not made." "I find it shocking," Brown said."This did not happen. There is no evidence that it happened other than Mr Murdoch's but it didn't happen. ...

item.title: Syrian forces shell towns, clash with rebels
item.description: BEIRUT (Reuters) - Syrian forces shelled opposition strongholds in the central province of Homs and eastern Deir al-Zor on Monday and clashed with rebels in violence which killed 29 people across the country, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said. The British-based Observatory, which monitors Syria through a network of sources inside the country, said six members of the security forces were killed in fighting with rebels in the town of Al-Ashaara in Deir al-Zor. A further five people, including an army defector, were killed in army shelling of the town, it said. ...

item.title: Syrian troops and rebels clash across country
item.description: Syrian troops attacked a rebel-held town in the center of the country with helicopter gunships on Monday and shelled other restive areas across the country, activists said.
item.media:text: Syrian troops attacked a rebel-held town in the center of the country with helicopter gunships on Monday and shelled other restive areas across the country, activists said.

item.title: Spain told it will be under "troika" supervision
item.description: MADRID/BERLIN (Reuters) - Spain faces supervision by international lenders after a bailout for its banks agreed at the weekend, EU and German officials said on Monday, contradicting Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy who had insisted the cash came without such strings. Financial markets responded with relief to Saturday's euro zone deal to lend Madrid up to 100 billion euros ($125 billion) to recapitalize debt-laden banks, with investors scooping up battered financial shares. The euro and European stocks jumped, with the Madrid stock exchange opening up 5. ...
item.media:text: MADRID/BERLIN (Reuters) - Spain faces supervision by international lenders after a bailout for its banks agreed at the weekend, EU and German officials said on Monday, contradicting Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy who had insisted the cash came without such strings. Financial markets responded with relief to Saturday's euro zone deal to lend Madrid up to 100 billion euros ($125 billion) to recapitalize debt-laden banks, with investors scooping up battered financial shares. The euro and European stocks jumped, with the Madrid stock exchange opening up 5. ...

item.title: Greek right-wing extremist who slapped woman sues
item.description: The spokesman for Greece's extreme-right Golden Dawn party, who caused uproar last week by slapping one female politician and throwing a glass of water on another on live TV, sued the two women Monday as well as the television channel that hosted the news show.
item.media:text: The spokesman for Greece's extreme-right Golden Dawn party, who caused uproar last week by slapping one female politician and throwing a glass of water on another on live TV, sued the two women Monday as well as the television channel that hosted the news show.

item.title: Insight: Demand soaring for pension transfers to insurers
item.description: BOSTON/NEW YORK (Reuters) - Last week's deal by Prudential Financial to take on $26 billion of the retirement liabilities of General Motors has reignited a part of the American insurance market that had been bouncing along the bottom in recent years. But experts in the sector say GM's splash was so big, there may be somewhat limited capacity for more mega-sized deals in the market for pension-risk transfers. Still, the market could be in the tens of billions over the next few years, they said. ...
item.media:text: BOSTON/NEW YORK (Reuters) - Last week's deal by Prudential Financial to take on $26 billion of the retirement liabilities of General Motors has reignited a part of the American insurance market that had been bouncing along the bottom in recent years. But experts in the sector say GM's splash was so big, there may be somewhat limited capacity for more mega-sized deals in the market for pension-risk transfers. Still, the market could be in the tens of billions over the next few years, they said. ...

item.title: Hispanic voters targeted in new ad blitz for Obama
item.description: One of the nation's largest unions and a Democratic super PAC supporting President Barack Obama launched a joint $4 million Spanish-language advertising campaign on Monday, targeting Hispanic voters.

item.title: Airline industry profits to plummet in 2012: IATA
item.description: Airline industry group IATA warned on Monday global profits would more than halve this year owing to surging oil prices and the eurozone crisis, with European carriers suffering losses of $1.1 billion.
item.media:text: Airline industry group IATA warned on Monday global profits would more than halve this year owing to surging oil prices and the eurozone crisis, with European carriers suffering losses of $1.1 billion.

item.title: Commerce secretary probed in car accidents
item.description: Commerce Secretary John Bryson was under investigation Monday in connection to two separate accidents in California which involved his car and two other vehicles, police said.
item.media:text: Commerce Secretary John Bryson was under investigation Monday in connection to two separate accidents in California which involved his car and two other vehicles, police said.

item.title: Italy stuck in deep economic recession
item.description: Official statistics confirm that Italy's economy contracted by a quarterly rate of 0.8 percent in the first three months of the year, the worst contraction in three years.

item.title: Spain bond rally reverses as bailout doubts set in
item.description: LONDON (Reuters) - Spanish government bond yields turned flat on the day, reversing an earlier fall, as relief after the country secured a banking bailout proved to be short-lived. Spanish 10-year yields rose to 6.26 percent, up 1.4 basis points on the day having earlier fallen to as low as 6.04 percent. Markets initially reacted positively to the news that Spain had agreed a bailout of up to 100 billion euros for its stricken banks. However, that sentiment gave way to doubts over how the bailout will be structured and whether the bailout solved the country's problems. ...

item.title: Pro-Hitler graffiti found at Israel's Holocaust museum
item.description: Hebrew graffiti thanking Hitler for the Holocaust and denouncing Zionism was sprayed at Jerusalem's Yad Vashem Holocaust museum on Monday, with suspicion falling on ultra-Orthodox opponents of the state of Israel.
item.media:text: Hebrew graffiti thanking Hitler for the Holocaust and denouncing Zionism was sprayed at Jerusalem's Yad Vashem Holocaust museum on Monday, with suspicion falling on ultra-Orthodox opponents of the state of Israel.

item.title: ICC sends team to Libya after delegation detained
item.description: TRIPOLI (Reuters) - Representatives of the International Criminal Court arrived in Tripoli on Sunday to try to secure the release of a detained delegation visiting Muammar Gaddafi's captured son, a Libyan official said. The four-member delegation was being held in the western mountain town of Zintan after one of its lawyers, Australian Melinda Taylor, was found carrying documents regarded as suspicious for Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, a Libyan lawyer and a militia member said on Saturday. The president of the international war crimes court demanded their immediate release. ...
item.media:text: TRIPOLI (Reuters) - Representatives of the International Criminal Court arrived in Tripoli on Sunday to try to secure the release of a detained delegation visiting Muammar Gaddafi's captured son, a Libyan official said. The four-member delegation was being held in the western mountain town of Zintan after one of its lawyers, Australian Melinda Taylor, was found carrying documents regarded as suspicious for Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, a Libyan lawyer and a militia member said on Saturday. The president of the international war crimes court demanded their immediate release. ...

item.title: Spain more likely to tap ESM bailout fund: German government
item.description: BERLIN (Reuters) - Spain is more likely to tap the euro zone's new permanent bailout facility, the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), than the current vehicle, the European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF), a spokesman for the German Finance Ministry said. The 17-nation euro zone agreed on Saturday to lend Spain up to 100 billion euros for its bank rescue fund in an attempt to reassure investors and erect a new firewall in the currency bloc's sovereign debt crisis. ...

item.title: Lebanese, Syrians seized in retaliatory abductions
item.description: BEIRUT (Reuters) - At least seven Lebanese and Syrian citizens have been kidnapped in northern Lebanon near the border with Syria, the first such reported abductions fuelled by tensions over the uprising in Syria that have spilled into its small neighbor. Residents said on Monday the abductions started on Saturday when a hardline Sunni Lebanese supporter of the Syrian revolt against President Bashar al-Assad was kidnapped by Lebanese Alawites. A string of tit-for-tat abductions along sectarian lines followed over the weekend, they said. ...

item.title: Insight: Portugal toughs it out as austerity bites
item.description: GRANDOLA, Portugal (Reuters) - To every Portuguese, the town of Grandola is a cradle of the 1974 revolution that ended decades of dictatorship, but nowadays it is hard to find even a spark of revolt here against the worst economic hardship in the country's recent history. A visit to Grandola inspired left-wing songwriter Zeca Afonso to write 'Grandola, Vila Morena', the song that was played on the radio to signal the start of the revolt. White-walled and now sleepy, the town nestles in the southern cork-growing region. ...

White-walled and now sleepy, the town nestles in the southern cork-growing region. ...
